mapped_themes.name: External Threat Intensity
mapped_themes.description: Severity of military pressure and barbarian invasions
mapped_themes.combined_description: Gibbon argues that the Roman Empire became 'too vast to be governed' effectively, leading to a strain on military resources and inability to defend its borders. He states that the 'barbarians' were 'invincible' and that their incursions contributed significantly to the empire's downfall.

mapped_themes.name: Internal Stability Level
mapped_themes.combined_description: Gibbon notes that 'the spirit of liberty was extinguished' by the rise of corruption among officials, undermining the integrity of governance. He emphasizes that the 'frequent changes of emperors' created instability, with many leaders lacking the necessary qualities to govern effectively.

mapped_themes.name: Economic Development Level
mapped_themes.combined_description: He highlights that 'the public revenue was diminished' due to over-taxation and the devaluation of currency, leading to economic instability.

mapped_themes.name: Socio-Cultural Vitality
mapped_themes.combined_description: Gibbon observes that 'the spirit of the people' declined as civic virtue waned, leading to a loss of social cohesion and responsibility. He notes that 'the decline of the Roman spirit' was marked by a lack of participation in civic duties, weakening the state. Gibbon notes that the empire experienced 'a loss of cultural unity,' with diverse populations leading to conflicting identities.

mapped_themes.name: Religious Influence Level
mapped_themes.combined_description: Gibbon argues that the rise of Christianity 'changed the character of the empire,' leading to internal divisions and a shift in cultural values.

mapped_themes.name: Governance System Efficiency
mapped_themes.combined_description: Gibbon points out that 'the vastness of the empire' led to 'inefficient administration,' complicating governance.
